posts.cooked:
Hello Everyone!

As you may know I am investing time into improving YAGSL from being JSON config based with configuration options able to be set from one off functions in SwerveDrive to something more easy to manage.

YAGSL will still have a way to configure your robots via JSON!

To do this I plan on creating a CTRE -Style SwerveDriveConfig , and SwerveModuleConfig , class with all optional improvements, optimizations, and required settings for a SwerveDrive .

This would allow for an easy way for users to create SwerveDrive without using the JSON in such a way that you could do.

The only problem is that this doesn’t lend itself well to situations where you are using a brushed motor because brushed motors would require a quadrature encoder attached to the azimuth or drive motor controllers. While i could add a bunch of configuration options for this it would be a burden on teams who rely on it, especially bc azimuths without a same vendor absolute encoder and a brushed motor would be the only way to avoid having a quadrature encoder.

Should we remove brushed motor support?

Should YAGSL remove brushed motor support? Yes No 0 voters

Should YAGSL remove brushed motor support? Yes No

Should YAGSL remove brushed motor support?

polls.name: poll
polls.title: Should YAGSL remove brushed motor support?

posts.name: MetabolicCloth
posts.cooked: What’s the value add for switching to the CTRE -style config class based configuration? If there’s still going to be a JSON based configuration option and this change is going to make brushed motors no longer an option. Is the idea that it makes it easier to build your configuration in code rather than JSON?

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked:
Swerve with brushed motors (in FRC , not sure about FTC and hobby projects) is dead.

However, everything else can still be done super competitively (if not more competitive in some cases due to packaging and wiring) with brushed. I would not want support for brushed in other libraries to disappear.

Just my 2¢

posts.name: MetabolicCloth
posts.cooked:
That’s a fair statement, and I don’t necessarily think that it needs to continue to be supported by YAGSL . The question was more about what’s prompting the change. Seems like a pretty large change to YAGSL , even if the JSON configuration remains the same.

I’m assuming that this change is likely intended for the 2026 season.
The idea is to have both be a valid option and make it easy. JSON isn’t able to configure everything with YAGSL as it is and the CTRE -style will help aleviate the pains that has caused.
It is a very large change. Partially inspired by the upcoming projects that are getting released, and future integrations with them.
What would you consider a valid use of brushed motors out of curiosity, outside of intakes?

posts.name: Karl Olson
posts.cooked:
For anything you would want to run through a slip ring, there are good arguments for a brushed motor with the controller before the slip ring.

Also packaging. Sometimes you might need a motor that is just the right size, and there are not that many legal brushless motors to have solved all the possibilities (even if many, possibly correctly for another variety of reasons, decide to design around that fact instead of use brushed motors).

Edit: fixed typo brushless → brushed

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked:
From a purely technical standpoint:

Indexers, single use mechanisms (such as drive-by scoring mechanisms teams have used for auto in the past (2018 switch)), turret hoods, end game mechanisms (e.g. 2023 edge walker by 118, 2024 Trap “sticks” by 2767), a variety of end effector applications, specialty game mechanics (2020 color wheel), slip rings as mentioned above.

Basically any lower power / low duty cycle application is feasible for brushed, perhaps even preferred. Especially if you don’t want the hassle/ vulnerability of CAN in the proximity (although with multiple CAN busses on offer with the 2027 controls this point is less critical)

posts.name: Dan Peled
posts.cooked:
We currently use a brushed motor for our azimuth motor,and we just used the absolute encoder as the encoder for itmotor is brushed, does that mean we won’t be able to use YAGSL with our current setup anymore?

I have also seen a fair amount of YAGSL teams with very simmilar setups all used brushed motors aswell (mostly neos, forgot what model)

Edit; apperantly the motor is brushed, mb

Thanks for pointing that out @nstrike

I think i found a good solution for now. I will add the in-code method to the mech lib. YAGSL will remain the same and I will do my annual maintenance as normal.

The mech lib version will not have maple sim support and will not support brushed motors. I will remove brushed motor support and merge them in 2027.
